text: One hundred ninety - one patients ( 31 % ) had a previous history of asthma or wheezing bronchitis and 54 of them ( 28 % ) were using an asthma controller therapy . Most had a mild exacerbation ( = 110 ; 57 % ) and 69 ( 36 % ) moderate , while only 12 ( 6 % ) presented a severe asthma attack . Sixteen percent of them required admission either to the short - stay observation or to the Pediatric Ward . Among the children with a previous asthma diagnosis , 95 ( 49 % ) were ≥ 6 years and 63 of them ( 67 % ) were not using any controller therapy ( either for no prescription or for no use ) . The severity of the exacerbations in patients who are ≥ 6 years with a previous diagnosis of asthma and divided into two subgroups ( controller therapy , no controller therapy ) is shown in Figure 3 : asthmatic patients not using a controller medication were more likely to have a moderate - to - severe exacerbation than their peers under long - term therapy ( < . 01 ) .
